In chapter IX » The Date of the Lycurgan Reforms « it is contended that modern views which would date the Eummia as late as c.  600 B.  C.  rest on unsound,  or misunderstood,  supports,  namely the decline of Spartan art and the cessation of foreign imports at about that date ; the supposed change in the tribal system,  whereby the three primitive Dorian tribes were replaced by five new ones ; and the chronology implied by Herodotus^s account of the reforms of Lycurgus.  In selecting Wade - Gery's arguments ( in CAH^ III ( 1925 ) ) as representative of modern views and in ignoring more recent discussions of the problem,  whether published by himself or by other historians,  especially in German periodicals,  the author appears to some extent to be tilting at abandoned wind - mills. 
Even if we accept her argument that the decline of Spartan art was due to influences affecting the Greek world as a whole ( though Corinthian art survived rather longer and Attic took a new lease of life ),  and concede that the evidence for the five new tribes is not as certain as could be wished,  there remains the difficulty caused by the statement of Herodotus ( i.  67 ).  The solution offered here ( pp.  329—33 ) is that H.  believed that there were two widely - separated unsuccessful wars,  to the first of which belongs the story of the fetters and of the capture of King Charillos ; and that his date must be the first half of the eighth century B.  C.  Thus the author's clusion is that the chronology of the Arcadian Wars does not support a date c.  600 B.  C.  for the Lycurgan reforms.  Further,  the quoit of Iphitus is explained as an Eleian forgery of the early fourth century and therefore of no historical value.  Having thus formulated her objections to the ments for the later dating of the reforms,  the author puts forward her reasons for assigning them to a much earlier date,  namely — ( i ) »That the Spartan King - lists preserve an accurate record of the number of tions which elapsed from the time of the Dorian invasion,  or for that matter,  even earlier« ( if so,  of what were they kings?  ) : and that the Agiad list is the more reliable since some lyric poet ( possibly Terpander himself ) at an early date provided a pedigree for the ruling king,  before the responding Eurypontid pedigree,  with its dubious order and improbable names ( Eunomos and Prytanis ) was composed to rival it. 
( 2 ) That with the aid of these lists it is possible to equate the traditions for the date of Lycurgus recorded by Herodotus and Thucydides,  if we accept a period of 27 years as the normal Spartan reckoning for a generation,  a legitimate inference from the Dorian fondness for multiples of three and nine.  ( How this is to be reconciled with the five Ephors is discussed later.
